author: tehnoodles
body:
At a very small scale software like DNAC or DCNM works ok. Try to scale this to 10,000's of nodes, and it starts to fall apart. I have seen this multiple different times, and this was using recommended compute hardware given to us by cisco to try and make it work.

The automation software crumbles when you reach scales the require automation, which completely defeats the purpose.

I also didn't say their hardware has issues. Aside from the usual bug schedule (which cisco is no better/worse than anyone else) their hardware is rocksolid, it really comes down to the software for the API on the devices, or the software of tools to manage it.

Cisco is only a leader in the market when you look at the entire breadth of their portfolio because: No one else is spread as thin. Only Juniper comes close and IMO and while i like SRX, it's not a while lot better than Firepower. Their ability to automate though? Leaps and bounds above cisco, and their hardware platform is arguable just as mature as any that cisco has on the market.

author: tendieshitter
body:
First off, visit [optionsprofitcalculator.com](https://optionsprofitcalculator.com) to get an idea what you would make with the move of an option. It's usually difficult to calculate given all the variables, but this site should help.

" say I expect the stock to hit $35.50 at some point that day and I would  sell it, I would want to buy a put option because I expect the stock to  go down on Monday. This protects me and provides me with the opportunity  to sell my 100 shares at $36.62 still, when the current price is  $35.50. Correct? "

No. If you expect a red Monday and you already own 100 shares of Cisco you plan to sell, you are already dealing with a loss. Furthermore, if you expect the price to go down further you would be good to buy a put contract on Cisco. 

If you want to hang on to your shares of Cisco because you expect them to go up, but want "insurance" against that, you could also buy a put contract in case the price goes down.

author: SUPER_swan
body:
The ESPP program you have is a great money maker for you.


Look at the last 10 years of the stock, not the last 6 months. Cisco has slowly gone up.


Lets say your required holding period is 1 year. That means if you hold the stock for 1 year and the stock doesn’t budge in price. If you sell you gain the 15% in the discount plus 4% from the dividend you gained as well. Historically, the stock has gone up as well, which also increase your gains.

So, continue to buy your company stock.


Now there is some people I bet at your work, just like mine, that have bought their company stock for 20+ years and never sold. Doing this increasing your exposure to that one company. If the company tanks, your stock will be worth a lot less and you could be out of a job.


However, if you go with selling right after your lock out period it’s a great way to use that discount to generate more money for you. 


Relax investing is a marathon not a sprint.

author: espresso_inflective
body:
>I'm sorry, but people stuck at home won't be buying fewer Apple products to entertain themselves with, even if there is a delay in receiving the product from Apple, and Cisco won't stop building the internet that more people will use when they quarantined at home, and people won't go on Twitter less when they stuck at home, or buy less bandaids from JNJ, or stop buying laundry detergent from PG.

All of these are examples of demand shock, which I think most people agree is not the issue here. The issue is a supply shock: Apple is going to produce less, Cisco is going to have trouble obtaining their parts, Twitter's advertisers are going to experience similar shocks and buy fewer advertisements, and PG is going to have trouble sourcing the inputs for its laundry detergent.

author: Bartlet4America94
body:
Copying my comment regarding RH suits:

If you file in court, they’ll move to dismiss, since the “proper” venue is via a FINRA arbitration. 

A bunch of these popping up will cause headaches, but it’ll probably be a copy-paste type motion to dismiss, so it won’t cost them that much $. Lack of PJ, improper venue, even SJ since it’s all federal securities (though many states have their own securities regulatory bodies).

Now, there are jurx that don’t follow mandatory arbitration (LA, NC) so technically those RH users in these states could file and not necessarily get bumped out on the MtD phase. However, since this is mainly federal stuff, I still think most courts will defer to FINRA.

The main strategy would be to file in court and then immediately leverage settlement before the judge rules on dismissal. Settlement for each individual case would be low and so would be the bargaining power of the potential plaintiff. You’d want to consolidate all actions into a class. The problem with this is it takes time and then you’ll have fights over class cert. that can move the settlement needle back and forth.

author: Salty_Cornflakes
body:
To all those crying about the death of WSB, here is a mod's response:

 

* We're working on it. We've made a few adjustments already that have helped immensely. I'd wager that 4/5 of the posts that you're complaining about don't even see the light of day. Which should impress and terrify you.
* It's difficult trying to strike a balance. The public attention has brought a lot of legitimate traders here who just want to share their experience, real DD, technical analysis, etc and we want to encourage that. They obviously make new accounts and we want them to contribute immediately.
* We're tweaking things everyday in response to rapidly changing growth and news that swings the entire sub in a matter of hours (like our pumping problem last week). This weeked now everyone is talking about their local Costco, committing bioterroism, and killing the pope. Also, please calm the fuck down with killing the pope, guys. It's borderline enciting violence, I've temp banned a few people who take it wayyyy too far.
* Our sexuality aside, we're volunteers from around the world. Our hours and availability differ, so there are mod lulls where a lot of one liner shitposts get through. We do our best, but we really focus on providing the best experience we can for you guys during trading hours when the engagement here is through the roof.
* As far as you or others wanting to volunteer, you guys actually do a pretty good job en mass with downvoting and reporting bullshit. Keep it up. We appreciate that.

That's all I got at the moment. Hope it gives you some kind of something.

author: Sikeitsryan
body:
since no ones helped you out

options are contracts entered into by you and someone else (a counter party). There's 2 types of options, puts and calls. If you look at OP's picture you'll see that one of his "trades" is for SQQQ $29 CALL 3/20.

So he wants to buy a call. Now, like I said this call is a contract between OP and someone else. This contract states that at anytime between the day that OP purchases the call contract and the expiration date of the contract, stated as 3/20/2020. OP has the 'option' or choice to buy 100 shares of the etf SQQQ from the counter party of the contract for $29 regardless of what the actual price of the ETF is.

&#x200B;

So theoretically, if on 3/15 SQQQ is trading at $50 a share, OP can exercise his option and buy those 100 shares for $29 dollars from the counter party and sell those shares immediately in the open market for $50. 

&#x200B;

The downside is that OP has to pay the counter party a 'premium' in order to have this option. Right now the premium has a bid/ask of $2.65 x 2.95. So if OP wants to buy the call he has to pay $2.95 x 100 (per share, remember the call gives op the right to buy 100 shares from the counter party). Now, you may be asking, why is the spread so wide? Wouldn't OP immediately lose $30 or 10% on his trade? Is OP gambling with probably zero actual insight on investing? I'll let you figure those out on your own.

author: cbreezy88
body: Really eying QCOM and COST leaps but don’t feel confident in buying yet. I think the floor is near but I don’t think it’s here yet

author: HallucinatoryFrog
body:
So far: T, VZ, NOK, ERIC, CMRE, REYN, QCOM, INTC

CMRE is the only one that I have gotten into based purely off COVID-19.  The rest are my 5G plays and REYN which I got into once they went public at the end of January.  They have weathered the dip quite well and I am glad that I added them to my consumer defensive stocks.  This one has been quite the sleeper since so many ppl were speculating on SPCE and then Coronavirus happened.

author: Autistictradeguy
body: I became interested in investing and have similar love for tech like you. I have great success day trading options on semiconductor stocks liKE $AMD and $INTC.  $NVDA, $MU, $$AMAT, are all good chip makers. For a couple of months I could choose any one of those tickers, buy a given otm call and pretty much be set. $QCOM is great too, practically a monopoly on ARM based architecture which is proabbaly the future of full size chips.
